publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l:
────────Quid non Mortalia pectora cogis
Auri sacra fames────────────
Fair ones; to you, who hearts command
And gently sway with fan in hand
Your favourite Punch a suppliant falls
And humbly for assistance calls
He humbly calls and begs you'll stop
The Gothick rage of Vander-Hop────
Who invades without pretence or right
Or any Law but that of Might
Our Pigmy-Land, and treats our Kings
Like petty, idle, wooden things
Has beat our dancers out of doors
And call'd our chastest virgins whores
He has not left our Queen a rag on
Has forc'd our George away, and Dragon
Has broke our wires, nor was he civil
To Doctor Faustus nor the Devil
Ev'n me he hurry'd with fell rage
Most hoarsely squalling off the stage
And faith our fright was very great
To see a Minister of State
Arm'd with Power and fury come
To force us from our little home
We fear'd (as I am sure we'd reason)
An accusation of High-Treason
'Till starting up, says Bannimier
Treeson, my friends, we need not fear
For 'gainst the Brass we us'd no Power
Nor strove to save the Chancellor
Nor did we shew the least affection
To Rochford──on the 'Meath election
Nor did we sing──Mc:Hugh he means
You Villain I'll dash out your brains
'Tis no affair of state that brings
Mme here, nor business of the Kings
I come to seize you all as debtors
And bind you fast in Iron-fetters
From sight of every friend in Town
'Till fifty pound to me's paid down
Fifty! quoth I──a devilish sum────
But stay 'till the brass-farthings come
Then we shall all be rich as Jews
From Castle down to lowest stews
That sum shall to you then be told
Tho' now we cannot furnish Gold
Quoth he, thou vile mishapen beast
Thou knave, am I become thy jest
And dost thou think that I am come
To carry nought, but farthings home
Thou fool, I ne'er do things by halves
Farthings were made for Irish slaves
No brass for me it must be Gold
Or fifty pounds in Silver told
That can by any means obtain
Freedom for thee and for thy train
Vôtre très humble Serviteur
I'm not in jest, said I, I'm sure
But from the bottom of my belly
I in sober sadness tell you
I thought it was good reasoning
For us fictitious men, to bring
Brass-counters made by Willṃ Wood
Which might as well be understood
Intrinsick, as we flesh and blood
Then since we are but mimick Men
Pray let us pay in mimick coin
Quoth he thou lovest Punch to prate
And would for ever hold debate
But thinkst thou, I have nought to do
But to stand prating thus with you
Therefore to stop your noisy parly
I do at once assure you fairly
That not a Puppet of you all
Shall stir a step within this wall
Nor merry-Andrew beat his drum
Untill you pay the aforesaid Sum
Then marching off with Swiftest pace
To write dispatches for his Gr────────────
The Revel-Master left the Room
And us condemn'd to fatal doom
Now; fair ones; If I e'er found grace
Or that my Jokes did ever please
Use all your interest with the Sec:────
(They say he's at the Ladies beck)
And tho' he thirsts as much for Gold
As ever Midas did of old
Your charms, I'm sure will never fail
Your eyes must influence, must prevail
At your command, he'll set us free
Let us to you owe Liberty
Get us a License now to Play
And we, in duty bound, will pray &c
Add too its said that you and I
Are of the selfsame family
And faith I'm apt to think so too
For who is liker me than you
For, the same grave and awkard grace
Shews forth it self in either face
And each of us with labour struts
Behind at least a tun of Guts
We tally well in those respects
But best of all in intellects,
And when upon a grave affair
Amaz'd you gaz'd behind the Chair
They cry'd how like a Punchanello
Is that same fat thick-headed fellow
Then pr'ythee Cozen let us buss
And cease to treat your kindred thus────Y08B008D
